docs.title: Objective
docs.text: Teach core Linux hardening principles: - Secure user accounts - Controlled privilege escalation - SSH hardening - Auditing and logging

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text:
• Base Linux VM (Ubuntu/Debian/CentOS)
  • Users: opsadmin, deploy, auditor
  • Privilege escalation via sudo, controlled by /etc/sudoers.d/
  • Logging via rsyslog and auditd

docs.title: Implementation Steps
docs.text:
1. Create users and groups
  2. opsadmin: sudo privileges
  3. deploy: limited deployment tasks
  4. auditor: read-only
  5. SSH hardening
  6. Disable root login: PermitRootLogin no
  7. Use key-based authentication: PubkeyAuthentication yes
  8. Disable password authentication: PasswordAuthentication no
  9. Configure sudo
  10. Fine-grained sudo access in /etc/sudoers.d/
  11. PAM enforcement
  12. Enable logging
  13. auditd for command tracking
  14. Syslog forwarding for central logging
  15. Test
  16. Confirm login restrictions
  17. Attempt prohibited commands

docs.title: Scripts & Configs
docs.text:
• scripts/create_users.sh
  • scripts/ssh_hardening.sh
  • configs/sudoers.fsie
  • configs/audit.rules

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
• Log in as deploy → cannot run restricted commands
  • Log in as opsadmin → can run allowed sudo commands
  • Confirm logs in /var/log/audit/audit.log

docs.title: Failure Modes
docs.text:
• Root SSH enabled → potential compromise
  • Misconfigured sudo → privilege escalation risk
  • Audit not running → missed security events

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: Configure secure networks and firewalls: - Segmentation and isolation - Firewall rules enforcement - Basic intrusion protection

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text:
• Servers: Linux VMs from Lab 2
  • Firewalls: iptables or firewalld
  • Network zones: DMZ, Internal, Admin

docs.title: 1. Define Network Zones
docs.text:
• DMZ: Public-facing services (web, API)
  • Internal: Application servers
  • Admin: Operations and management

docs.title: 2. Configure Firewall Rules
docs.text:
• Allow SSH only from Admin zone
  • Allow HTTP/HTTPS from DMZ
  • Block all other traffic

Example iptables.rules snippet:

```bash *filter

docs.title: Default policies
docs.text: :INPUT DROP [0:0] :FORWARD DROP [0:0] :OUTPUT ACCEPT [0:0]

docs.title: Allow loopback
docs.text: -A INPUT -i lo -j ACCEPT -A OUTPUT -o lo -j ACCEPT

docs.title: Allow established connections
docs.text: -A INPUT -m state --state ESTABLISHED,RELATED -j ACCEPT

docs.title: SSH from Admin network
docs.text: -A INPUT -p tcp -s 192.168.10.0/24 --dport 22 -j ACCEPT

docs.title: HTTP/HTTPS from DMZ
docs.text: -A INPUT -p tcp -s 192.168.20.0/24 --dport 80 -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -p tcp -s 192.168.20.0/24 --dport 443 -j ACCEPT

docs.title: Drop invalid packets
docs.text: -A INPUT -m state --state INVALID -j DROP

docs.title: Reject everything else
docs.text:
-A INPUT -j REJECT --reject-with icmp-port-unreachable -A FORWARD -j REJECT --reject-with icmp-port-unreachable

COMMIT

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This directory contains configuration files and scripts used for Lab 3 Network Firewalls Configuration. The lab focuses on implementing, testing, and verifying firewall rules in a network environment, simulating real-world enterprise security practices.

These configs are designed to help you: - Understand and implement firewall rules. - Secure network traffic between hosts and subnets. - Practice basic to advanced packet filtering, NAT, and port forwarding. - Learn how firewalls interact with other network devices and policies.
